headline: Fed's rate decision, Oracle & Broadcom earnings: What to Watch
summary: Market Domination Overtime host Josh Lipton takes a look at the top stories for investors to watch next week, starting Monday, Dec. 8. Another wave of earnings is on tap: Toll Brothers (TOL) on Monday, Campbell's (CPB) and Cracker Barrel (CBRL) on Tuesday, Oracle (ORCL) and Adobe (ADBE) on Wednesday, Broadcom (AVGO) and Costco (COST) on Thursday, and Rent the Runway (RENT) on Friday, among others. The Small Business Association's (SBA's) National Federation of Independent Business (NFIB) will release its monthly Small Business Optimism Index. The Federal Reserve's December meeting will kick off on Tuesday, while the FOMC's decision on interest rates will be announced on Wednesday. Tune in to Yahoo Finance on Wednesday, Dec. 10 at 2:00 p.m. for live coverage of Fed Chair Jerome Powell's post-decision press conference. To watch more expert insights and analysis on the latest market action, check out more Market Domination Overtime.

headline: Fed Meeting, Broadcom Earnings: What to Watch Next Week
summary: The Federal Reserve will finish its last meeting of 2025 this coming week, and investors are expecting a quarter-point interest rate cut that would bring the benchmark range to 3.5% to 3.75%. A few notable earnings updates are also expected before the holiday season takes over.

raw.headline: Fed Meeting, Broadcom Earnings: What to Watch Next Week
raw.summary: The Federal Reserve will finish its last meeting of 2025 this coming week, and investors are expecting a quarter-point interest rate cut that would bring the benchmark range to 3.5% to 3.75%. A few notable earnings updates are also expected before the holiday season takes over.

headline: Why Adobe (ADBE) Stock Is Trading Up Today
summary: Shares of creative software giant Adobe (NASDAQ:ADBE) jumped 5.5% in the afternoon session after the stock's momentum improved as the company continued its significant share buyback program. Adobe's share repurchases resulted in a net buyback yield nearing 8%, signaling confidence to investors. The positive investor reaction came as Barclays maintains an "Overweight" rating. The move also occurred ahead of the company's fourth-quarter results, for which analysts forecasted growth in both revenue

headline: The Week in Numbers: Thanksgiving sales surge, Disney's China record
summary: STORY: From a Thanksgiving holiday sales surge to a Disney film breaking Chinese records...This is the Week in Numbers.:: Week in Numbers:: $44 billion$44 billion was how much U.S. shoppers spent online over the Thanksgiving weekend.Consumers bought up during the five-days from Thanksgiving to Cyber Monday as retail giants like Amazon and Walmart rolled out discounts.The data came from an Adobe Analytics report.It showed spending was up 7.7% from a year earlier and beat Adobe's forecast.:: 10% 10% is how much Boeing shares jumped after a positive report.Investors bought in after the planemaker said it expects higher jet deliveries and positive free cash flow next year.Boeing wants to improve its image after a 5-year corporate crisis involving safety and production issues of its 737 series.The issues have hit its reputation and sent the U.S. major deeply into debt:: $1.5 billion$1.5 billion is how much Prada spent to buy out fellow Italian fashion brand Versace.Prada had long sought the deal and signed an agreement in April to purchase the decades-old firm from U.S.-based Capri Holdings.The late Gianni Versace founded his luxury brand known for its glamorous style in 1978.His sister Donatella stepped down as creative head earlier this year.:: 10.6%10.6% was the sales growth rise for Zara owner Inditex in November.It's a crucial period for retailers due to the Black Friday weekend.It also confirmed a strong start to the fashion major's biggest revenue quarter.One analyst said the Spanish company may have its home market to thank due to the country's strong economy.:: $275.6 millionAnd $275.6 million was how much Disney's Zootopia 2 made in its first six days of release in China.That means it has become the highest-grossing animated foreign film ever in the country.Zootopia 2 made up around 95% of all movie ticket sales over its opening weekend.It comes just months after Beijing cut the number of U.S. films allowed in China due to its trade war with Washington.

after the planemaker said it expects higher jet deliveries and positive free cash flow next year.Boeing wants to improve its image after a 5-year corporate crisis involving safety and production glamorous style in 1978.His sister Donatella stepped down as creative head earlier this year.:: 10.6%10.6% was the sales growth rise for Zara owner Inditex in November.It's a crucial period for foreign film ever in the country.Zootopia 2 made up around 95% of all movie ticket sales over its opening weekend.It comes just months after Beijing cut the number of U.S. films allowed in China due
